html.display_name: Electric Field of a Line Charge
html.p: A long straight wire carries a charge per unit length [mathjaxinline]\lambda[/mathjaxinline]. What is the electric field a distance [mathjaxinline]d[/mathjaxinline] from the wire? Find this field in two different ways, first using Coulomb's Law, and then using Gauss's Law.
The "Chapters 22 and 23" which Prof. Lewin mentions are for the textbook used at that time. This information can be found in Chapters 2 & 3 of the 8.02r e-textbook.

Note: In the second part of the solution, Prof. Lewin uses the notation "ds" for a small surface element instead of the more typical "dA". Except for this different notation, all the discussion of Gauss' Law is identical to what that you will see elsewhere.
